Description: A chisel of rectangular section: slightly pitted by corrosion although the metal surfaces have now been cleaned. The cutting edge has been hammered from both sides of the tool, but has never been finally sharpened by grinding.
Curator's comments: Perhaps the reason why the chisel was not sharpened is because it was made specifically for the funeral equipment and therefore did not need to be functional. Bibliography: W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (Cairo, 1954), 61, no. 230, fig. 75 and pl. XXXIb. For other examples of Early Dynastic copper chisels, see E. Amélineau, ‘Les Nouvelles Fouilles d’Abydos’ II (1896-7), pl.XVIII; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pl.XXXV, 91; XXXVIII, 94; XLI, 93; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl.L; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), pl.XV, 1, 8, 10; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pl.V, 6, 8, 12; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan I and Memphis V' (London, 1913), pls.IV, 3-5, 8; VI, 4, 10; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tools and weapons : illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University College, London' (London, 1917), 19-20 and pls.XXI-XXII; G. A. Reisner, 'The early dynastic cemeteries of Naga-ed-Dêr' I, (California, 1908), 115 and pl.40d; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' I' (Cairo, 1949), 42-6 and pl.9B; W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (London, 1954), 61 and pl.XXXIb; J. E. Quibell, ‘Archaic Objects’ (Cairo, 1905), nos. 14540-1. 14556-7 and pl.59; J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara, 1912-1914: Archaic Mastabas’ (Cairo, 1923), pl.VIII, 1; J. E. Quibell & F. W. Green, 'Hierakonpolis' II (London, 1989), 26 and pl.XLVIIIb; C. M. Firth and J. E.
